revision.text:
{{Infobox civil conflict | title = 1934 West Coast waterfront strike |image = Confrontation between a policeman wielding a night stick and a striker during the San Francisco General Strike, 1934 - NARA - 541926.jpg | caption = Confrontation between a policeman wielding a night stick and a striker during the San Francisco General Strike, 1934. |place = [[Everett, Washington]];
[[Portland, Oregon]];
[[San Francisco, California]];
[[Seattle, Washington]] |date = May 9, 1934 – July 31, 1934{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XipsuAAACAAJ|title=Labor's giant step: twenty years of the CIO.|last=Preis|first=Art|date=1974|publisher=Pathfinder Press|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=31–33|language=en}} | map_type = | map_caption = | map_size = | coordinates = | latitude = | longitude = | goals = | methods = [[Strike action|Strikes]], [[Protest]], [[Demonstration (people)|Demonstrations]] | status = | result = | concessions = | side1= [[International Longshoremen's Association]] | side2= [[California Army National Guard|California National Guard]] | leadfigures1= [[Harry Bridges]];
Paddy Morris;
Jack Bjorklund;
Joseph P. Ryan | leadfigures2= [[Frank Merriam]];
[[Angelo Joseph Rossi|Angelo Rossi]];
[[Julius Meier]] | casualties1= '''Deaths''': 9,
'''Injuries''':>1000,
'''Arrests''': >500.{{Cite book|url=https://publishing.cdlib.org/ucpressebooks/view?docId=ft6d5nb46p;brand=ucpress|title=Reds or Rackets?: The Making of Radical and Conservative Unions on the Waterfront|last=Kimeldorf|first=Howard|date=1988-11-04|publisher=University of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520912779|location=|pages=101|language=en}} | casualties2= '''Deaths''':
'''Injuries''': | casualties_label= Arrests, etc | strength1= | strength2= }} The '''1934 West Coast Waterfront Strike''' (also known as the '''1934 West Coast Longshoremen's Strike''', as well as a number of variations on these names) lasted eighty-three days, and began on May 9, 1934 when longshoremen in every [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]] port walked out. The [[Strike action|strike]] peaked with "Bloody Thursday" and the '''San Francisco General Strike''' which [[General strike|stopped all work]] in the major port city for four days and led ultimately to the settlement of the West Coast Longshoremen's Strike. The result of the strike was the [[unionization]] of all of the West Coast ports of the United States. The San Francisco General Strike of 1934, along with the [[Auto-Lite strike|Toledo Auto-Lite Strike of 1934]] led by the [[American Workers Party]] and the [[Minneapolis Teamsters Strike of 1934]] led by the [[Communist League of America]], were important catalysts for the rise of [[industrial unionism]] in the 1930s, much of which was organized through the [[Congress of Industrial Organizations]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XipsuAAACAAJ|title=Labor's giant step: twenty years of the CIO.|last=Preis|first=Art|date=1974|publisher=Pathfinder Press|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=31–33|language=en}} ==Background== [[Longshoremen]] on the West Coast ports had either been unorganized or represented by [[company union]]s since the years immediately after [[World War I]], when the shipping companies and stevedoring firms had imposed the [[open shop]] after a series of failed strikes.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7GvgN0y7yI4C|title=Endangered Dreams: The Great Depression in California|last=Starr|first=Kevin|date=1997|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780195118025|location=|pages=85-86|language=en}} Longshoremen in San Francisco, then the major port on the coast, were required to go through a hiring hall operated by a company union, known as the "blue book" system for the color of the membership book.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yj0lDQAAQBAJ|title=From Mission to Microchip: A History of the California Labor Movement|last=Glass|first=Fred|date=2016-06-28|publisher=Univ of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520288409|location=|pages=231|language=en}} The [[Industrial Workers of the World]] had attempted to organize longshoremen, sailors and fishermen in the 1920s through their Marine Transport Workers Union.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jTwUeGYCcD8C|title=Workers on the Waterfront: Seamen, Longshoremen, and Unionism in the 1930s|last=Nelson|first=Bruce|date=1990|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=|isbn=9780252061448|location=|pages=60|language=en}} Their largest strike, the [[1923 san pedro maritime strike|1923 San Pedro Maritime Strike]], bottled up shipping in that harbor, but was crushed by a combination of injunctions, mass arrests and vigilantism by the [[American Legion]]. While the IWW was a spent force after that strike, [[syndicalism|syndicalist]] thinking remained popular on the docks.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jTwUeGYCcD8C|title=Workers on the Waterfront: Seamen, Longshoremen, and Unionism in the 1930s|last=Nelson|first=Bruce|date=1990|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=|isbn=9780252061448|location=|pages=61-62|language=en}} Longshoremen and sailors on the West Coast also had contacts with an Australian syndicalist movement that called itself the "[[One Big Union (concept)|One Big Union]]" formed after the defeat of a [[Australian general strike, 1917|general strike there in 1917]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jTwUeGYCcD8C|title=Workers on the Waterfront: Seamen, Longshoremen, and Unionism in the 1930s|last=Nelson|first=Bruce|date=1990|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=|isbn=9780252061448|location=|pages=64-65|language=en}} The [[Communist Party USA|Communist Party]] had also been active in the area in the late 1920s, seeking to organize all categories of maritime workers into a single union, the Maritime Workers Industrial Union (MWIU), as part of the drive during the [[Third Period]] to create revolutionary unions.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=39|language=en}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jTwUeGYCcD8C|title=Workers on the Waterfront: Seamen, Longshoremen, and Unionism in the 1930s|last=Nelson|first=Bruce|date=1990|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=|isbn=9780252061448|location=|pages=79|language=en}} The MWIU never made much headway on the West Coast, but it did attract a number of former [[IWW]] members and foreign-born militants.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jTwUeGYCcD8C|title=Workers on the Waterfront: Seamen, Longshoremen, and Unionism in the 1930s|last=Nelson|first=Bruce|date=1990|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=|isbn=9780252061448|location=|pages=62|language=en}} [[Harry Bridges]], an Australian-born sailor who became a longshoreman after coming to the United States, would be accused over and over for his acknowledged Communist party membership.http://depts.washington.edu/dock/Harry_Bridges_intro.shtml{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7GvgN0y7yI4C|title=Endangered Dreams: The Great Depression in California|last=Starr|first=Kevin|date=1997|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780195118025|location=|pages=93|language=en}} Militants published a newspaper, ''The Waterfront Worker'', which focused on longshoremen's most pressing demands: more men on each gang, lighter loads and an independent union.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yj0lDQAAQBAJ|title=From Mission to Microchip: A History of the California Labor Movement|last=Glass|first=Fred|date=2016-06-28|publisher=Univ of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520288409|location=|pages=232|language=en}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7GvgN0y7yI4C|title=Endangered Dreams: The Great Depression in California|last=Starr|first=Kevin|date=1997|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780195118025|location=|pages=90|language=en}} While a number of the individuals in this group were Communist Party members, the group as a whole was independent of the party: although it criticized the [[International Seamen's Union]] (ISU) as weak and the [[International Longshoremen's Association]] (ILA), which had its base on the [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]], as corrupt, it did not embrace the MWIU, but called instead for creation of small knots of activists at each port to serve as the first step in a slow, careful movement to unionize the industry. Events soon made the MWIU wholly irrelevant. Just as the passage of the [[National Industrial Recovery Act]] had led to a spontaneous explosion in union membership among coal miners in 1933, thousands of longshoremen now joined the fledgling ILA locals that reappeared on the West Coast.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=40|language=en}} The MWIU faded away as party activists followed the mass of West Coast longshoremen into the ILA. These newly emboldened workers first went after the "blue book" union, refusing to pay dues to it and tearing up their membership books. The militants who had published "The Waterfront Worker", now known as the "Albion Hall group" after their usual meeting place, continued organizing dock committees that soon began launching [[slowdown]]s and other types of job actions in order to win better working conditions. While the official leadership of the ILA remained in the hands of conservatives sent to the West Coast by President Joseph Ryan of the ILA, the Albion Hall group started in March, 1934 to press demands for a coastwide contract, a union-run hiring hall and an industry wide waterfront federation.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7GvgN0y7yI4C|title=Endangered Dreams: The Great Depression in California|last=Starr|first=Kevin|date=1997|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780195118025|location=|pages=94-95|language=en}} When the conservative ILA leadership negotiated a weak "gentlemen's agreement" with the employers that had been brokered by the mediation board created by the administration of President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], Bridges led the membership in rejecting it.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=42-44|language=en}} The sticking point in the strike was recognition: the union demanded a [[closed shop]], a coastwide contract and a union hiring hall. The employers offered to arbitrate the dispute, but insisted that the union agree to an open shop as a condition of any agreement to arbitrate. The longshoremen rejected the proposal to arbitrate.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=41-42|language=en}} ==The Big Strike== [[File:Battle of Smith Cove commemorative billy club 01.jpg|thumb|left|An engraved billy club commemorates police activity in the Battle of [[Smith Cove (Washington)|Smith Cove]] in Seattle.]] The strike began on May 9, 1934, as longshoremen in every West Coast port walked out; sailors joined them several days later.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7GvgN0y7yI4C|title=Endangered Dreams: The Great Depression in California|last=Starr|first=Kevin|date=1997|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780195118025|location=|pages=90-91|language=en}} The employers recruited [[strikebreaker]]s, housing them on moored ships or in walled compounds and bringing them to and from work under police protection.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7GvgN0y7yI4C|title=Endangered Dreams: The Great Depression in California|last=Starr|first=Kevin|date=1997|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780195118025|location=|pages=91|language=en}} Strikers attacked the stockade housing strikebreakers in San Pedro on May 15; police fired into the strikers and killed one and injured scores. The killing of Dick Parker created resentment up and down the coast.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=50|language=en}} Daily similar smaller clashes broke out in San Francisco and [[Oakland, California]], [[Portland, Oregon]],{{cite web|last1=Munk|first1=Michael|title=West coast waterfront strike of 1934|url=https://oregonencyclopedia.org/articles/west_coast_waterfront_strike_of_1934/#.WPKqW0Xyvcs|website=Oregon Encyclopedia|accessdate=15 April 2017}} and [[Seattle|Seattle, Washington]]. Strikers also succeeded in slowing down or stopping the movement of goods by rail out of the ports.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=49-50|language=en}} The Roosevelt administration tried again to broker a deal to end the strike, but the membership twice rejected the agreements their leadership brought to them and continued the strike.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7GvgN0y7yI4C|title=Endangered Dreams: The Great Depression in California|last=Starr|first=Kevin|date=1997|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780195118025|location=|pages=100-101|language=en}} The employers then decided to make a show of force to reopen the port in San Francisco.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=102|language=en}} On Tuesday, July 3, fights broke out along the [[Embarcadero, San Francisco|Embarcadero]] in San Francisco between police and strikers while a handful of trucks driven by young businessmen made it through the picket line.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=103-105|language=en}} Some [[Teamsters]] supported the strikers by refusing to handle "hot cargo" – goods which had been unloaded by strikebreakers, although the Teamsters' leadership was not as supportive.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=48-49|language=en}} By the end of May [[Dave Beck]], president of the Seattle Teamsters, and Mike Casey, president of those in San Francisco, thought the maritime strike had lasted too long.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=80|language=en}} They encouraged the strikers to take what they could get from the employers and threatened to use Teamsters as strikebreakers if the ILA did not return to work.[http://www.ilwu19.com/history/1934.htm Longshoreman's Strike of 1934] - ILWU =="Bloody Thursday"== {{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 200 |image1=Record of Death for Howard Sperry.jpg |alt1=San Francisco Coroner's Record of Death for Howard Sperry |image2=Record of death for Nicolas Bordoise.jpg |alt2=San Francisco Coroner's Record of Death for Nicolas Bordoise |footer=San Francisco Coroner's Records of Death for Howard Sperry and Nicolas Bordoise }} After a quiet Fourth of July the employers' organization, the Industrial Association, tried to open the port even further on Thursday, July 5.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=110|language=en}} As spectators watched from [[Rincon Hill]], the police shot [[tear gas]] canisters into the crowd, then followed with a charge by [[mounted police]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=111|language=en}} Picketers threw the canisters and rocks back at the police, who charged again, sending the picketers into retreat.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=112|language=en}} Each side then refortified and took stock.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yj0lDQAAQBAJ|title=From Mission to Microchip: A History of the California Labor Movement|last=Glass|first=Fred|date=2016-06-28|publisher=Univ of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520288409|location=|pages=239-40|language=en}} The events took a violent turn that afternoon, as hostilities resumed outside of the ILA strike kitchen.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=113|language=en}} Eyewitness accounts differ on the exact events that transpired next. According to some witnesses, a group of strikers first surrounded a police car and attempted to tip it over, prompting the police to fire shotguns in the air, and then revolvers at the crowd. Other eyewitness accounts claim that police officers started shooting in the direction of the strikers, provoking strikers to defend themselves. Policemen fired a shotgun into the crowd, striking three men in intersection of Steuart and Mission streets. One of the men, Howard Sperry, a striking longshoreman, later died of his wounds. Another man, Charles Olsen, was also shot but later recovered from his wounds. A third man, Nick Bordoise – a Greek by birth (originally named Nick Counderakis) who was an out of work member of the cook's union volunteering at the ILA strike kitchen – was shot but managed to make his way around the corner onto Spear Street, where he was found several hours later. Like Sperry, he died at the hospital.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7GvgN0y7yI4C|title=Endangered Dreams: The Great Depression in California|last=Starr|first=Kevin|date=1997|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780195118025|location=|pages=107-8|language=en}} Strikers immediately cordoned off the area where the two picketers had been shot, laying flowers and wreaths around it. Police arrived to remove the flowers and drive off the picketers minutes later. Once the police left, the strikers returned, replaced the flowers and stood guard over the spot. Though Sperry and Bordoise had been shot several blocks apart, this spot became synonymous with the memory of the two slain men and "Bloody Thursday."{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=119|language=en}} As strikers carried wounded picketers into the ILA union hall police fired on the hall and lobbed tear gas canisters at nearby hotels. At this point someone reportedly called the union hall to ask "Are you willing to arbitrate now?"{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=113|language=en}} Under orders from [[Governor of California|California Governor]] [[Frank Merriam]], the [[California Army National Guard|California National Guard]] moved in that evening to patrol the waterfront.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7GvgN0y7yI4C|title=Endangered Dreams: The Great Depression in California|last=Starr|first=Kevin|date=1997|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780195118025|location=|pages=108|language=en}} Similarly, federal soldiers of the [[United States Army]] stationed at the [[Presidio of San Francisco|Presidio]] were placed on alert. The picketers pulled back, unwilling to take on armed soldiers in an uneven fight, and trucks and trains began moving without interference. Bridges asked the San Francisco Labor Council to meet that Saturday, July 7, to authorize a general strike.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=122|language=en}} The [[Alameda County]] Central Labor Council in Oakland considered the same action. Teamsters in both San Francisco and Oakland voted to strike, over the objections of their leaders, on Sunday, July 8.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=123|language=en}} ==Funerals and general strike== The following day, several thousand strikers, families and sympathizers took part in a funeral procession down Market Street, stretching more than a mile and a half, for Nicholas Bordois and Howard Sperry, the two persons killed on "Bloody Thursday".{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yj0lDQAAQBAJ|title=From Mission to Microchip: A History of the California Labor Movement|last=Glass|first=Fred|date=2016-06-28|publisher=Univ of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520288409|location=|pages=240|language=en}} The police were wholly absent from the scene. The march made an enormous impact on San Franciscans, making a general strike, which had formerly been "the visionary dream of a small group of the most radical workers, became . . . a practical and realizable objective."words of Paul Eliel, ''Waterfront and General Strikes'' pg. 128, quoted in {{cite book|last1=Bruce|first1=Nelson|title=Workers on the Waterfront: Seamen, Longshoremen, and Unionism in the 1930s|date=1990|publisher=University of Illinois Press|page=303|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jTwUeGYCcD8C&pg=PA303|accessdate=15 April 2017}} After dozens of Bay Area unions voted for a general strike over the next few days, the San Francisco Labor Council voted on July 14 to call a general strike.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=138, 141|language=en}} The Teamsters had already been out for two days by that point.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=133|language=en}} San Francisco Mayor [[Angelo Joseph Rossi|Angelo Rossi]] declared a [[state of emergency]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4dpWCgAAQBAJ|title=Politics of US Labor|last=Milton|first=David|date=1982|publisher=NYU Press|year=|isbn=9780853455707|location=|pages=50|language=en}} Some federal officials, particularly [[Secretary of Labor]] [[Frances Perkins]], were more skeptical.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=142|language=en}} Roosevelt later recalled that some persons were urging him to steer the [[USS Houston (CA-30)|USS Houston]], which was carrying him to [[Hawaii]], "into [[San Francisco Bay]], all flags flying and guns double-shotted, and end the strike." Roosevelt rejected the suggestion.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4dpWCgAAQBAJ|title=Politics of US Labor|last=Milton|first=David|date=1982|publisher=NYU Press|year=|isbn=9780853455707|location=|pages=49|language=en}} The general strike began on the 16th, involving some 150,000 workers.{{Cite journal|last=Chretien|first=Todd|date=June 2012|title=The Communist Party, the unions, and the San Francisco General Strike|url=https://isreview.org/issue/84/communist-party-unions-and-san-francisco-general-strike|journal=International Socialist Review|volume=84|pages=|via=}} On the 17th the police arrested more than 300 "radicals, subversives, and communists" while systematically smashing furniture and equipment of organizations related to the strike; the same day, General [[Hugh S. Johnson]] as head of the [[National Recovery Administration]] spoke at [[University of California, Berkeley|UC Berkeley]] to denounce the general strike as "a menace to the government."{{cite web|last1=Carlsson|first1=Chris|title=The General Strike of 1934|url=http://www.foundsf.org/index.php?title=The_General_Strike_of_1934|website=Found SF|accessdate=15 April 2017}} The strike lasted four days. Non-union truck drivers joined the first day; the movie theaters and night clubs closed down. While food deliveries continued with the permission of the strike committee, many small businesses closed, posting signs in support of the strikers.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=151|language=en}} Reports that unions in Portland and Seattle would also begin general strikes picked up currency.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=173|language=en}} ==End of the strike== The calling of a general strike had an unexpected result: it gave the General Strike Committee, whose makeup was far less militant than the longshoremen's strike committee, effective control over the maritime strike itself.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=156-157|language=en}} When the Labor Council voted to terminate the general strike it also recommended that the unions accept [[arbitration]] of all disputed issues.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=176|language=en}} When the National Longshore Board put the employer's proposal to arbitrate to a vote of striking longshoremen, it passed in every port except [[Everett, Washington]]. That, however, left the striking seamen in the lurch: the employers had refused to arbitrate with the ISU unless it first won elections on the fleets on strike. While Bridges, who had preached solidarity among all maritime workers and scorned arbitration, apologized to the seamen for the longshoremen's vote, the President of the ISU urged them to hold out and to burn their "fink books", the membership records of the company union to which they had been forced to pay dues.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yj0lDQAAQBAJ|title=From Mission to Microchip: A History of the California Labor Movement|last=Glass|first=Fred|date=2016-06-28|publisher=Univ of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520288409|location=|pages=244|language=en}} On July 17, 1934, the [[California National Guard]] blocked both ends of Jackson Street from Drumm to Front with machine gun mounted trucks to assist vigilante raids, protected by [[SFPD]], on the headquarters of the Marine Workers' Industrial Union and the [[International Longshoremen's Association|ILA]] soup kitchen at 84 Embarcadero. Moving on, the Workers' Ex-Servicemen's League's headquarters on Howard between Third and Fourth was raided, leading to 150 arrests and the complete destruction of the facilities. The employer's group, the Industrial Association, had agents riding with the police.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=160|language=en}} Further raids were carried out at the Workers' Open Forum at 1223 Fillmore street and the Western Worker building opposite City Hall that contained a bookstore and the main offices of the Communist Party, which was thoroughly destroyed.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=161|language=en}} Attacks were also perpetrated on the 121 Haight Street Workers' School and the Mission Workers' Neighborhood House at 741 Valencia Street.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=162|language=en}} A police spokesperson suggested that "maybe the Communists staged the raids themselves for publicity".{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bOJKfeRxPsMC|title=A Terrible Anger: The 1934 Waterfront and General Strikes in San Francisco|last=Selvin|first=David F.|date=1996|publisher=Wayne State University Press|year=|isbn=0814326102|location=|pages=200|language=en}} General [[Hugh S. Johnson]], then head of the [[National Recovery Administration]], gave a speech urging responsible labor leaders to "run these subversive influences out from its ranks like rats".{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yj0lDQAAQBAJ|title=From Mission to Microchip: A History of the California Labor Movement|last=Glass|first=Fred|date=2016-06-28|publisher=Univ of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520288409|location=|pages=243|language=en}} A lawyer for the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] was kidnapped and beaten, while vigilantes seized thirteen radicals in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] and turned them over to the sheriff of an adjoining county, who transported them to another county.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=167|language=en}} In [[Hayward, California|Hayward]] in Alameda County someone erected a scaffold in front of the city hall with a noose and a sign stating "Reds beware".{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EAWUlxO9zSEC|title=The Big Strike|last=Quin|first=Mike|date=1979|publisher=International Publishers Co|year=|isbn=9780717805044|location=|pages=166|language=en}} In [[Piedmont, California|Piedmont]], an upscale community surrounded by Oakland on all sides, the chief of police prepared for a reported attack by strikers on the homes of wealthy ship-owners. An Exercise in Hysteria: San Francisco's Red Raids of 1934 - David F. Selvin - The Pacific Historical Review, Vol. 58, No. 3 (Aug., 1989), pp. 361-374 ==Aftermath== While some of the most powerful people in San Francisco considered the strike's denouement to be a victory for the employers, many longshoremen and seamen did not. Spontaneous strikes over grievances and workplace conditions broke out as strikers returned to their jobs, with longshoremen and teamsters supporting their demands.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jTwUeGYCcD8C|title=Workers on the Waterfront: Seamen, Longshoremen, and Unionism in the 1930s|last=Nelson|first=Bruce|date=1990|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=|isbn=9780252061448|location=|pages=156-157|language=en}} Employers conceded many of these battles, giving workers even more confidence in demanding that employers lighten unbearably heavy loads.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jTwUeGYCcD8C|title=Workers on the Waterfront: Seamen, Longshoremen, and Unionism in the 1930s|last=Nelson|first=Bruce|date=1990|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=|isbn=9780252061448|location=|pages=158|language=en}} Longshoremen also began dictating other terms, fining members who worked more than the ceiling of 120 hours per month, filing charges against a gang boss for "slandering colored brothers" and forcing employers to fire strikebreakers.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yj0lDQAAQBAJ|title=From Mission to Microchip: A History of the California Labor Movement|last=Glass|first=Fred|date=2016-06-28|publisher=Univ of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520288409|location=|pages=244-45|language=en}} Other unions went further: the [[Marine Firemen's Union|Marine Firemen]] proposed to punish any member who bought a [[William Randolph Hearst|Hearst]] newspaper.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jTwUeGYCcD8C|title=Workers on the Waterfront: Seamen, Longshoremen, and Unionism in the 1930s|last=Nelson|first=Bruce|date=1990|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=|isbn=9780252061448|location=|pages=160|language=en}} The arbitration award issued on October 12, 1934, cemented the ILA's power.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yj0lDQAAQBAJ|title=From Mission to Microchip: A History of the California Labor Movement|last=Glass|first=Fred|date=2016-06-28|publisher=Univ of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520288409|location=|pages=245|language=en}} While the award put the operation of the hall in the hands of a committee of union and employer representatives, the union was given the power to select the dispatcher. Since longshoremen were prepared to walk out if an employer did not hire a worker dispatched from the hall, the ILA soon controlled hiring on the docks. The employers complained that the union wanted to "sovietize" the waterfront.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jTwUeGYCcD8C|title=Workers on the Waterfront: Seamen, Longshoremen, and Unionism in the 1930s|last=Nelson|first=Bruce|date=1990|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=|isbn=9780252061448|location=|pages=162-163|language=en}} Workers complained that the employers were exploiting them for cheap labor and forcing them to work in unsafe conditions without reasonable safety measures. The union soon utilized the "quickie strike" tactic to force many concessions from employers such as safer working conditions and better pay.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pZMW4nqxwDAC|title=Reds or Rackets?: The Making of Radical and Conservative Unions on the Waterfront|last=Kimeldorf|first=Howard|date=1988-11-04|publisher=University of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520912779|location=|pages=112|language=en}} Similarly, even though an arbitrator held that the 1935 Agreement prohibited [[sympathy strike]]s, the union's members nonetheless refused to cross other unions' picket lines. Longshoremen also refused to handle "hot cargo" destined for non-union warehouses that the union was attempting to organize.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pZMW4nqxwDAC|title=Reds or Rackets?: The Making of Radical and Conservative Unions on the Waterfront|last=Kimeldorf|first=Howard|date=1988-11-04|publisher=University of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520912779|location=|pages=114|language=en}} The ISU acquired similar authority over hiring, despite the philosophical objection of the union's own officers to hiring halls. The ISU used this power to drive strikebreakers out of the industry.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jTwUeGYCcD8C|title=Workers on the Waterfront: Seamen, Longshoremen, and Unionism in the 1930s|last=Nelson|first=Bruce|date=1990|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=|isbn=9780252061448|location=|pages=164-166|language=en}} The rift between the seamen's and longshoremen's unions deepened and became more complex in the succeeding years, as Bridges continually fought with the [[Sailors' Union of the Pacific]] over labor and political issues. The West Coast district of the ILA broke off from the International in 1937 to form the International Longshoremen's Union, later renamed the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union after the union's "march inland" to organize warehouse workers, then renamed the [[International Longshore and Warehouse Union]] in recognition of the number of women members. The arbitration award also gave longshoremen a raise to ninety-five cents an hour for straight time work, just shy of the dollar an hour it demanded during the strike. It was also awarded a contract that applied up and down the West Coast.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yj0lDQAAQBAJ|title=From Mission to Microchip: A History of the California Labor Movement|last=Glass|first=Fred|date=2016-06-28|publisher=Univ of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520288409|location=|pages=245|language=en}} The strike also prompted union organizer [[Carmen Lucia (union organizer)|Carmen Lucia]] to organize the Department Store Workers Union and the Retail Clerks Association in San Francisco.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8SSa4uq6dYgC&pg=PA34#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Rocking the Boat: Union Women's Voices, 1915-1975|last=O'Farrell|first=Brigid|publisher=Rutgers University Press|year=1996|isbn=|location=New Brunswick, NJ|pages=40|via=Google Books}} ==Legacy== The ILWU continues to recognize "Bloody Thursday" by shutting down all West Coast ports every July 5 and honoring Nick Bordoise, Howard Sperry and all of the other workers killed by police during the strike.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yj0lDQAAQBAJ|title=From Mission to Microchip: A History of the California Labor Movement|last=Glass|first=Fred|date=2016-06-28|publisher=Univ of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520288409|location=|pages=246|language=en}} The ILWU has frequently stopped work for political protests against, among other things, Italy's [[Second Italo-Abyssinian War|invasion]] of Ethiopia, [[fascism|fascist]] intervention in [[Spanish civil war|Spain's civil war]], South Africa's system of [[apartheid]] and the [[Iraq War]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pZMW4nqxwDAC|title=Reds or Rackets?: The Making of Radical and Conservative Unions on the Waterfront|last=Kimeldorf|first=Howard|date=1988-11-04|publisher=University of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520912779|location=|pages=114|language=en}} Sam Kagel, the last surviving member of the original union steering committee, died on May 21, 2007 at the age of 98.{{cite news|last1=Nolte|first1=Carl|title=Sam Kagel -- arbitrator in major labor disputes (obit)|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Sam-Kagel-arbitrator-in-major-labor-disputes-2573764.php|accessdate=15 April 2017|publisher=SF Gate|date=27 May 2007}} ==See also== {{Portal|San Francisco Bay Area|Organized labour}} * [[Everett massacre]] * [[Harry Bridges]] * [[History of the west coast of North America]] * [[Murder of workers in labor disputes in the United States]] and General Strikes in San Francisco'', by David F. Selvin. Wayne State University Press (July 1996). {{ISBN|0-8143-2610-2}}. * ''Dock Strike: History of the 1934 Waterfront Strike in Portland, Oregon'', by Roger Buchanan * ''Reds or Rackets, The Making of Radical and Conservative Unions on the Waterfront'', by Howard Kimeldorf, {{ISBN|0-520-07886-1}} * ''Harry Bridges, The Rise and Fall of Radical Labor in the U.S.'', by Charles Larrowe, {{ISBN|0-88208-001-6}} * ''Workers on the Waterfront, Seamen, Longshoremen and Unionism in the 1930s'', by Bruce Nelson, {{ISBN|0-252-06144-6}} * ''Agitate, Educate, Organize: Portland, 1934'', by William Bigelow & Norman Diamond, Oregon Historical Quarterly, Spring 1988 * {{Oregon Encyclopedia|west_coast_waterfront_strike_of_1934}} * [http://depts.washington.edu/dock/34strike_intro.shtml 1934: The Great Strike], a multimedia section of the [[Waterfront Workers History Project]], including film and photographs of the strike, a day-by-day account of the strike and digitized copies of newspaper articles and worker newsletters. === Archives === * [http://archive.ilwu.org Anne Rand Library, International Longshore and Warehouse Union.] contains digitized materials related to the history of the ILWU, including 1934 strike bulletins. * [http://www.calisphere.universityofcalifornia.edu/browse/keyword/general+strike+1934 San Francisco General Strike of 1934 photographic collections], via Calisphere, California Digital Library *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130801120716/http://content.lib.washington.edu/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT=%2Fkccollects&CISOPTR=611&CISOBOX=1&REC=6 Police uniform from a longshoreman strike 1934.] At the [http://content.lib.washington.edu/imls/kccollects/index.html King County Collects Collections]. *[http://digital.lib.washington.edu/findingaids/view?docId=InternationalLongshoremensandWarehousemensUnionLocal4307.xml International Longshoremen’s and Warehousemen’s Union Local 1 Records.] 1933-1988. 4.58 cubic ft. (5 boxes).
