revision.comment: /* References */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Experimental brain research → Experimental Brain Research
revision.text:
[[File:Self-regulated learning.png|thumb|300px|A feedback model of the motivation-volition process. Lower labels are terminology of Zimmerman.<ref name=Schmitz/><ref name=Zimmerman/>]] In [[cognitive psychology|psychological]] theories of [[motivation]], the '''Rubicon model''', more completely the '''Rubicon model of action phases''', makes a distinction between motivational and volitional processes. The Rubicon model "defines clear boundaries between motivational and action phases". The first boundary "separates the motivational process of the predecisional phase from the volitional processes of postdecisional phase."<ref name=Achtziger/> Another boundary is that between initiation and conclusion of an action.<ref name=Achtziger/> A self-regulatory feedback model incorporating these interfaces was proposed later by others, as illustrated in the figure.<ref name=Schmitz/>
The name "Rubicon model" derives from the tale of Caesar's [[Point of no return|crossing the Rubicon River]], a point of no return, thereby revealing his intentions. According to the Rubicon model, every action includes such a point of no return at which the individual moves from goal setting to goal striving.<ref name=Rauber/><ref name=Corno/> :"Once subjects move from planning and goal-setting to the implementation of plans, they cross a metaphorical Rubicon. That is, their goals are typically protected and fostered by self-regulatory activity rather than reconsidered or changed, often even when challenged." ::— Lyn Corno, ''The best laid plans'', p. 15 (quoted by Rauber)
The Rubicon model addresses four questions, as identified by Achtziger and [[Peter Gollwitzer|Gollwitzer]]:<ref name=Achtziger/> #How do people select their goals? #How do they plan the execution of their goals? #How do they enact their plans? #How do they evaluate their efforts to accomplish a specific goal?
The study of these issues is undertaken by both the fields of [[cognitive neuroscience]] and [[social psychology]]. A possible connection between these approaches is brain imaging work attempting to relate volition to [[neuroanatomy]].<ref name=Brass/>
==Background== Human action coordinates such aspects of human behavior as perception, thought, emotion, and skills to classify goals as attainable or unattainable and then to engage or disengage in trying to attain these goals. According to Heckhausen & Heckhausen,<ref name=Heckhausen/> "Research based on the Rubicon model of action phases has provided a wealth of empirical evidence for mental and behavioral resources being orchestrated in this manner." Engagement and disengagement with goals affects personal distress over the unachievable. "By having new goals available, and reengaging in those new goals, a person can reduce distress....while continuing to derive a sense of purpose in life by finding other pursuits of value."<ref name=Wrosch/>
==See also== *[[Cognitive psychology]] *[[Executive functions]] *[[Delayed gratification]] *[[Motivation]] *[[Self-control]] *[[Self-efficacy]] *[[Self-regulated learning]] *[[Self-regulation theory]]
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name=Achtziger> {{cite book |chapter=Chapter 11: Motivation and volition in the course of action |author1=A Achtziger |author2=PM Gollwitzer |url=http://www.psych.nyu.edu/gollwitzer/10_Achtziger_Gollwitzer_motivation_and_volition.pdf |pages=272–295 |editor1=J. Heckhausen |editor2=H. Heckhausen |title=Motivation and action |isbn=9780521852593 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |edition=Paperback 2nd |year=2010}} </ref>
<ref name=Brass> {{cite journal |title=Imaging volition: what the brain can tell us about the will |author1=Marcel Brass |author2=Margaret T Lynn |author3=Jelle Demanet |author4=Davide Rigoni |doi=10.1007/s00221-013-3472-x |date=March 21, 2013 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Margaret_Lynn/publication/235983232_Imaging_volition_what_the_brain_can_tell_us_about_the_will/links/00b7d5152f3c64ead4000000.pdf |journal=Experimental Brain Research |pages=301–312 |volume=229 |number=3}} </ref>
<ref name=Corno> {{cite journal |author= Lyn Corno |year=1993 |title=The Best-Laid Plans: Modern Conceptions of Volition and Educational Research |journal=Educational Researcher |volume= 22 |issue=2 |pages=14–22 |doi=10.3102/0013189x022002014 |jstor=1176169}} </ref>
<ref name=Heckhausen> {{cite book |chapter=Chapter 1: Motivation and action: Introduction and overview |author1=J Heckhausen |author2=H Heckhausen |url=http://assets.cambridge.org/97805218/52593/excerpt/9780521852593_excerpt.htm |editor1=J. Heckhausen |editor2=H. Heckhausen |title=Motivation and action |pages=1–9 |isbn=978-0521149136 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |edition=Paperback 2nd |year=2010}} </ref>
<ref name=Rauber> {{cite web |author=Michael Rauber |url=http://kops.uni-konstanz.de/bitstream/handle/123456789/12223/0714_NONCOGNITIVE_SKILLS_082007.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y |title= Noncognitive skills and success in life: the importance of motivation and self-regulation |year= 2007 |work=Technical Report |publisher=KOPS – University of Konstanz}} </ref>
<ref name=Schmitz> {{cite journal |title=New perspectives for the evaluation of training sessions in self-regulated learning: Time-series analyses of diary data |author1=Bernhard Schmitz |author2=Bettina S. Wiese |journal=Contemporary Educational Psychology |volume=31 |year=2006 |pages=64–96 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Bettina_Wiese/publication/240205154_New_perspectives_for_the_evaluation_of_training_sessions_in_self-regulated_learning_Time-series_analyses_of_diary_data/links/0deec53516e0e399f4000000.pdf |doi=10.1016/j.cedpsych.2005.02.002}} See Figure 1: Component model of regulated learning. </ref>
<ref name=Wrosch> {{cite journal |url=http://crdh.concordia.ca/wrosch_lab/Publications/pdfs/PSPB_UG_2003.pdf |title=Self-regulation of unattainable goals: Goal disengagement, goal reengagement, and subjective well-being |author1=C Wrosch |author2=ME Scheier |author3=GE Milller |author4=R Schulz |author5=CS Carver |doi=10.1177/0146167203256921 |date=December 2003 |pages=1494–1508 |volume=29 |issue=12 |journal=Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin}} </ref>
<ref name=Zimmerman> {{cite book |title=Handbook of self-regulation |chapter=Chapter 2: Attaining self-regulation. A social cognitive perspective |author=Barry J Zimmerman |year=2005 |isbn= 978-0123695192 |editor1=M Boekaerts |editor-link1=Monique Boekaerts |editor2=PR Pintrich |editor3=M Zeidner |pages=13–39 |publisher=Academic Press}} For a similar figure, see [https://books.google.com/books?id=u9e1RWMbtjEC&pg=PA16&dq=%22Cyclical+phases+of+self-regulation%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=4IspVYH1IdbSoAT08oD4BQ&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Cyclical%20phases%20of%20self-regulation%22&f=false Figure 2, p. 16]. </ref> }}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}}
[[Image:Sajal barui, 1997.jpg|thumb|Sajal Barui in 1997.]] '''Sajal Barui''' ({{lang-bn|সজল বারুই}}) is a convicted criminal who is serving a life sentence in prison for the murder of his father, stepmother, and stepbrother. He committed the murders at the age of sixteen, on 22 November 1993 in [[Kolkata]], [[India]].<ref name="India today">{{cite web |last=Ghosh |first=Labonita |year=2006 |url=http://www.india-today.com/webexclusive/dispatch/20000408/20000408labonita.html |title=Killer Kids in India Today web exclusive |accessdate=7 October 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060509041352/http://www.india-today.com/webexclusive/dispatch/20000408/20000408labonita.html |archivedate=9 May 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> The murders made headlines in the Kolkata press due to the gruesome nature of the crimes and because Barui and his accomplices were minors at the time.<ref name="India today">{{cite web |last=Ghosh |first=Labonita |year=2006 |url=http://www.india-today.com/webexclusive/dispatch/20000408/20000408labonita.html |title=Killer Kids in India Today web exclusive |accessdate=7 October 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060509041352/http://www.india-today.com/webexclusive/dispatch/20000408/20000408labonita.html |archivedate=9 May 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="Bitscape info">{{cite web|last=Kumar |first=Kanti |date=1 September 1999 |url=http://bitscape.info/bitscape/research/the-trend-of-violence-on-the-indian-screen-its-influence-on-children/40/ |title=The Sajal Barui case ''in'' The Trend of Violence on the Indian Screen & its Influence on Children (KK Birla Foundation Fellowship Report) |accessdate=7 October 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928202713/http://bitscape.info/bitscape/research/the-trend-of-violence-on-the-indian-screen-its-influence-on-children/40/ |archivedate=28 September 2007 }}</ref><ref name="netguru">{{cite web|last=Staff Reporter |first= |year=2003 |url=http://www.calonline.com/news/Sep01/17/CAL2.html |title=Young killer escapes from hospital |accessdate=7 October 2006 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref name="Telegraph1">{{cite news | last = Mondal | first = Pronab | date = 17 May 2003 | url = http://telegraphindia.com/1030517/asp/calcutta/story_1976639.asp | title = Jailer nails Sajal Barui, aka Sk Raju | accessdate = 7 October 2006 | location=Calcutta, India | work=The Telegraph }}</ref>
==Early childhood== Sajal Barui's father, Subal Barui, abandoned his first wife, Neoti Barui, by whom he bore a son, and had a relationship with another woman, Minati.<ref name="Bitscape info"/> Sajal was conceived out of this affair.<ref name="Bitscape info"/> After a few years, his father returned to his first wife and took Sajal along with him. Sajal did not see his natural mother after the age of eight.<ref name="Bitscape info"/> After his arrest, he recounted how he had often been burned with burning cigarettes and hot irons in his childhood.<ref name="Bitscape info"/>
==The murders== On the night of 22 November 1993, Sajal and five of his friends, all of the same age, arrived at his residence in north Kolkata. Finding his stepmother alone, the group gagged her and tied her up to a chair.<ref name="Bitscape info"/> A similar fate befell his stepbrother when he arrived home, and also his father, shortly before midnight. Sajal and one of his accomplices, Ranjit, initially tried to murder the three victims by [[strangling]] them, but only the stepmother succumbed.<ref name="Bitscape info"/> Unable to kill his father and stepbrother, Sajal and Ranjit hacked and [[stabbing|stabbed]] them to death. The entire ordeal took nearly three hours.<ref name="Bitscape info"/>
After committing the crimes, on Sajal's directions, his friends cleaned their weapons with [[mustard oil]] and neatly organised them on the table.<ref name="Bitscape info"/> Exhausted with the exertion, they ate a few [[Bengali cuisine#Mishţi (sweets)|Bengali sweets]] from the refrigerator, and left a few coins on the table as "payment" for the food, an idea that had occurred to Sajal from watching a television programme.<ref name="Bitscape info"/>
Before Sajal's friends left, they tied him up to a chair and gagged him, to give the appearance that he was a victim too.<ref name="India today">{{cite web |last=Ghosh |first=Labonita |year=2006 |url=http://www.india-today.com/webexclusive/dispatch/20000408/20000408labonita.html |title=Killer Kids in India Today web exclusive |accessdate=7 October 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060509041352/http://www.india-today.com/webexclusive/dispatch/20000408/20000408labonita.html |archivedate=9 May 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="Bitscape info"/> Initially, he was able to allay suspicions.<ref name="netguru"/> However, the [[Kolkata Police]] became suspicious, since he showed no signs of a struggle or any other injuries.<ref name="India today">{{cite web |last=Ghosh |first=Labonita |year=2006 |url=http://www.india-today.com/webexclusive/dispatch/20000408/20000408labonita.html |title=Killer Kids in India Today web exclusive |accessdate=7 October 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060509041352/http://www.india-today.com/webexclusive/dispatch/20000408/20000408labonita.html |archivedate=9 May 2006 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> Upon interrogation, he confessed to committing the murders and detailed the crimes. Neither he nor his accomplices showed any signs of remorse. Even when the death sentence was announced, the group chose to clap and sing in unison.<ref name="Bitscape info"/> Later, the [[Calcutta High Court]] reduced the sentence to life imprisonment.
==Escape== Initially Sajal Barui had been serving his sentence at the [[Dum Dum]] Cantonment, but he was moved to [[Midnapore]] Central Jail in July 2000 due to "administrative problems".<ref name="Statesman">{{cite web|last=Staff Reporter |first= |date=16 September 2001 |url=http://www.thestatesman.net/page.arcview.php?clid=1&id=9639&usrsess=1 |title=Sajal Barui escapes from custody |accessdate=7 October 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929091234/http://www.thestatesman.net/page.arcview.php?clid=1&id=9639&usrsess=1 |archivedate=29 September 2007 }}</ref> In 2001, while serving his prison sentence, Sajal Barui showed signs of an alleged kidney ailment and was transferred to [[Calcutta National Medical College|Calcutta National Medical College and Hospital]] for examination.<ref name="netguru"/><ref name="Telegraph1"/> On 15 September 2001 he escaped from the hospital and was at large until early 2003.<ref name="Telegraph1"/><ref name="Telegraph3">{{cite news | last = Staff reporter | first = | date = 22 May 2003 | url = http://telegraphindia.com/1030517/asp/calcutta/story_1976639.asp | title = Two beer bottles to freedom | accessdate = 7 October 2006 | location=Calcutta, India | work=The Telegraph }}</ref> On the night of his escape, Sajal Barui hosted a beer party to which he invited the two [[police constable]]s that had been put on guard to watch him.<ref name="Telegraph3"/> He often offered beer to the constables after it had been smuggled in by his girlfriend, so they did not suspect his motives.<ref name="Telegraph3"/> On that night, however, he spiked the two bottles of beer with [[sleeping pill]]s and watched them fall asleep.<ref name="Telegraph3"/> He then walked out of the hospital unhindered.<ref name="Telegraph3"/>
==As a fugitive== After escaping from the police, Sajal Barui emailed a friend in [[Mumbai]] and fled there.<ref name="Telegraph3"/> He married there and returned to Kolkata, leaving his wife in [[Asansol]].<ref name="Telegraph3"/> He committed a number of crimes under various aliases.<ref name="Telegraph3"/> Police officers of the [[Phoolbagan]] and [[Maniktala]] Police Stations of Calcutta were nearly successful in recapturing Sajal Barui in early 2003, after they were able to trace his girlfriend and set up a sting operation to recapture him. However, Sajal Barui did not show up for the arranged rendezvous.<ref name="Telegraph1"/> Sajal Barui then took refuge in the den of a local criminal known as ''Hathkata'' Bishu (Bengali for one-armed Bishu) in [[Lake Town, Kolkata]]. He worked with Bishu, under the alias Kamal, and was responsible for a robbery in the [[Ultadanga]] area of Kolkata.<ref name="Telegraph1"/> As the search for Kamal intensified, Sajal Barui, migrated to Jamboni, in [[West Midnapore]] district, to work for Rajeev Meti, a local criminal.<ref name="Telegraph1"/>
==Recapture== In late February 2003, a criminal who went by the name of Sheikh Raju was arrested for petty theft in the Jamboni area of [[West Midnapore]] district and was brought to Midnapore Central Jail.<ref name="Telegraph1"/> On 16 May 2003, after masquerading as Sheikh Raju for almost three months, this criminal was positively identified as Sajal Barui by a jailer who had met him earlier when he was serving his life sentence at the [[Alipore]] Central Jail in Kolkata.<ref name="Telegraph1"/>
On recapture, Sajal Barui was sent to the Presidency Jail in Kolkata. Here, he formed a network with the terrorist Aftab Ansari, the prime accused in the [[Terrorist attack on American cultural centre in Kolkata (2002)|2002 terrorist attack on the American Center in Kolkata]], and [[Debashish Chakraborty]], a criminal convicted of killing his girlfriend and attempting to kill his mother.<ref name="TOI">{{cite news | last = Sen | first = Saibal | date = 23 March 2005 | url = http://www1.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/articleshow/msid-1060696,prtpage-1.cms | title = It's still raining ransoms for Aftab | accessdate = 7 October 2006 | work=The Times of India }}</ref><ref name="Debashish">{{cite news | last = Staff Reporter | first = | date = 30 May 2005 | url = http://www.telegraphindia.com/1050530/asp/bengal/story_4803582.asp | title = Lifer tracked down to uncle's home | accessdate = 7 October 2006 | location=Calcutta, India | work=The Telegraph }}</ref> Soon after this criminal nexus was discovered, Sajal Barui was shifted to the Alipore Central Jail.<ref name="TOI"/> Debashish Chakraborty was moved to Midnapore Central Jail, from which he escaped on 28 May 2005, only to be recaptured two days later.<ref name="Debashish"/> After serving some time in jail Sajal Barui was released in August 2010. In June 2011, he was arrested on charges of robbery.<ref name=Telegraph> {{Cite news |title = Family killer held for dacoity | url=http://telegraphindia.com/1110628/jsp/calcutta/story_14169470.jsp|accessdate=28 June 2011 |work= The Telegraph |location=Calcutta, India |date=28 June 2011}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Barui, Sajal}} [[Category:Criminals from Kolkata]] [[Category:Indian prisoners sentenced to life imprisonment]] [[Category:Prisoners sentenced to life imprisonment by India]] [[Category:Indian escapees]] [[Category:Escapees from Indian detention]] [[Category:Indian people convicted of murder]] [[Category:Minors convicted of murder]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by India]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox military person |name= Same (John) Shaw |birth_date= |death_date= 27 December 1859 |birth_place= [[Prestonpans]], [[East Lothian]] |death_place= |placeofburial=[[Buried at sea]] |image=Victoria Cross Medal without Bar.png |image_size=125 |caption= |nickname= |allegiance= {{UK}} |serviceyears= |rank=[[Corporal]] |branch=[[File:Flag of the British Army.svg|23px]] [[British Army]] |commands= |unit=[[The Rifle Brigade]] |battles=[[Crimean War]]
[[Indian Mutiny]] |awards= [[Victoria Cross]] |laterwork= }}'''Same (John) Shaw''' [[Victoria Cross|VC]] (Unknown – 27 December 1859) was a [[Scotland|Scottish]] recipient of the [[Victoria Cross]], the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to [[United Kingdom|British]] and [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] forces. ==Details== Shaw was a [[Private (rank)|private]] in the 3rd Battalion, [[The Rifle Brigade (Prince Consort's Own)]], [[British Army]] during the [[Indian Mutiny]] when the following deed took place on 13 June 1858 at [[Lucknow]], [[India]] for which he was awarded the VC: {{quote|Rifle Brigade (3rd Battalion)
Private Same Shaw
Date-of Act of Bravery, 13th June, 1858.
For the Act of Bravery recorded in a despatch from Major-General James Hope Grant, K.C.B., Commanding the Lucknow Field Force, to the Deputy Adjutant-General of the Army, of which the following is an extract:
"Nowabegunge, 17th June, 1858. "I have to bring to notice the conduct of Private Same Shaw, of the 3rd Battalion, Rifle Brigade, who is recommended by his Commanding Officer for the Victoria Cross, An armed rebel had been seen to enter a tope of trees. Some officers and men ran into the tope in pursuit of him. This man was a Ghazee. Private Shaw drew his short sword, and with that weapon rushed single-handed on the Ghazee. Shaw received a severe tulwar wound, but after a desperate struggle, he killed the man." " I trust his Excellency will allow me to recommend this man for the Victoria Cross, and that he will approve of my having issued a Division Order, stating that I have done so."{{London Gazette|issue=22194|page=4575|date=18 June 1858}}}} He later achieved the rank of [[corporal]]. ==The medal== His Victoria Cross is displayed at the [[Royal Green Jackets (Rifles) Museum]], [[Winchester]], England. ==References== {{Reflist}} *[[Monuments to Courage]] (David Harvey, 1999) *[[The Register of the Victoria Cross]] (This England, 1997) *[[Scotland's Forgotten Valour]] (Graham Ross, 1995) {{DEFAULTSORT:Shaw, Same (John)}} [[Category:British recipients of the Victoria Cross]] [[Category:Rifle Brigade soldiers]] [[Category:1859 deaths]] [[Category:Indian Rebellion of 1857 recipients of the Victoria Cross]] [[Category:Burials at sea]] [[Category:People from Prestonpans]] [[Category:British Army personnel of the Crimean War]] [[Category:British Army recipients of the Victoria Cross]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:People who died at sea]]

[[File:Heinz Haber Wernher von Braun Willy Ley (1954).jpg|thumb|400px|Von Braun holds a model of a bottle-suit also called a single person spacecraft]]
A '''single-person spacecraft''' is a vehicle designed for space travel.<ref name="auto">{{Cite news|url=https://www.space.com/39573-single-person-spacecraft-passes-pool-test.html|title=Single-Person Spacecraft Design Passes Pool Test|work=Space.com|access-date=2018-02-05}}</ref> The concept has been used in [[science fiction]] and actual ships<ref name="auto"/> such as the [[Project Mercury|Mercury capsule]], [[Vostok 1|Vostok]] and some suborbital designs. Single-person spacecraft have been envisioned as a supplement or replacement for [[space suit]]s in certain applications. The Von Braun Bottle suit of the 1950s functions as a hybrid of a space suit and a one-person spacecraft.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cyberneticzoo.com/teleoperators/1954-bottle-suit-wernher-von-braun-walt-disney-american/|title=1954 - "Bottle Suit" - Wernher von Braun / Walt Disney (American) - cyberneticzoo.com|date=31 August 2014|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://cyberneticzoo.com/teleoperators/1954-bottle-suit-wernher-von-braun-walt-disney-american/|title=1954 - "Bottle Suit" - Wernher von Braun / Walt Disney (American) - cyberneticzoo.com|date=2014-08-31|work=cyberneticzoo.com|access-date=2018-03-29|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Capsule-suits== [[Image:Bruce McCandless II during EVA in 1984.jpg|thumb|right|280px|The Shuttle EMU coupled with the manned maneuvering unit enable untethered omnidirectional spaceflight for one]] [[File:NASA Ames-X5 hard space suit.jpg|thumb|NASA AX-5 hard space suit]] The idea of a space-suit is that of a man-sized capsule, something beyond form-fitting space suits and rigid suits similar to [[Extravehicular activity|EVA.]]
[[Wernher von Braun|Werner Von Braun]], known for the moonshot project, proposed a conical bottle suit in the 1950s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mix.msfc.nasa.gov/abstracts.php?p=1459|title=9605274 - Dr. von Braun Discusses "Bottle Suit" Concept|website=mix.msfc.nasa.gov}}</ref> In 1965, the Grumman moon suit had a hard bottle enclosure allowing the user's arms to fully retract into the suit.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gizmodo.co.uk/2012/03/a-pressure-suit-for-every-occasion-and-atmosphere/|title=A Pressure Suit for Every Occasion and Atmosphere|website=Gizmodo UK|language=en|access-date=2018-02-28}}</ref>
In the 1970s, NASA worked on the AX-3 Hardsuit.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gizmodo.co.uk/2012/03/a-pressure-suit-for-every-occasion-and-atmosphere/|title=A Pressure Suit for Every Occasion and Atmosphere|website=Gizmodo UK|language=en|access-date=2018-02-08}}</ref> In the 1980s, [[Ames Research Center|NASA Ames]] center developed the AX-5 hard suit to avoid having to pre-breathe for lower-pressure suits than the host spacecraft.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/multimedia/images/2010/iotw/ax_5_astronaut.html|title=NASA - History of Ames - X5 Astronaut Suit|website=www.nasa.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-02-07}}</ref> A NASA space suit with some hard elements (named the I-Suit), was developed later.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://gizmodo.com/5892080/a-pressure-suit-for-every-occasion-and-atmosphere/|title=A Pressure Suit for Every Occasion and Atmosphere|last=Oobject.com|first=David Galbraith -|work=Gizmodo|access-date=2018-02-08|language=en-US}}</ref>
The [[Manned Maneuvering Unit]] is noted in regard to the single-person spacecraft, and it was tested in space in 1984 during a [[Space Shuttle]] launch.<ref name="auto"/> Highly compact single-person spacecraft have been considered by [[International Space Station|ISS]] for EVA work, to avoid having to go through the decompression needed to use the lower-pressure space suits.<ref name="nasa.gov">[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20120013602.pdf Benefits of a Single-Person Spacecraft for Weightless Operations Brand Norman Griffin ]</ref> NASA developed a body-shaped single person spacecraft called FlexCraft, with the idea of allowing more and shorter EVA.<ref name="nasa.gov"/> The spacecraft would be at the same atmospheric pressure as the ISS, thus removing the medical stress and time needed to decompress and compress, and the danger of [[Decompression sickness|the bends]].<ref name="nasa.gov"/> A single-person spacecraft could also enhance protection against [[Micrometeoroid|micrometeoriod]] impacts and radiation from cosmic rays.<ref name="nasa.gov"/>
The [[Personal Rescue Enclosure]] was developed for the Space Shuttle. On the ISS the combination of a Space Suit, the [[Simplified Aid For EVA Rescue]] (SAFER) and [[Extravehicular Mobility Unit]] are used, combined to form a soft-suit spacecraft for emergencies.
A demonstration of single-person spacecraft for ISS, called the FlexCraft, was proposed in the 2010s.<ref name="nasa.gov1">[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20120016580.pdf Low Cost Space Demonstration for a Single-Person Spacecraft Brand N. Griffin1]</ref> In 2018 a single person spacecraft capsule tested in a water pool by NASA.<ref name="Space.com">{{Cite news|url=https://www.space.com/39573-single-person-spacecraft-passes-pool-test.html|title=Single-Person Spacecraft Design Passes Pool Test|work=Space.com|access-date=2018-09-10}}</ref> This design has a hatch at the bottom that an astronaut could enter into, but it would be at full pressure thus avoiding the need to purge nitrogen from the body for low-pressure suits.<ref name="Space.com"/> The capsule suit has little robotic arms, and might be able used for some of the tasks currently done in space suits, but the capsule suit would have enhanced micrometeoroid protection and a higher pressure atmosphere.<ref name="Space.com"/>
=== List of capsule-suits === *NASA FlexCraft <ref name="nasa.gov"/> *Von Braun Bottle Suit<ref name="auto"/><ref name="nasa.gov"/> *Bell Labs Remora<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.space.com/39573-single-person-spacecraft-passes-pool-test.html|title=Single-Person Spacecraft Design Passes Pool Test|publisher=}}</ref> *University of Maryland Scout<ref name="nasa.gov"/> *Manned Autonomous Workstation (MAWS)<ref name="nasa.gov"/><ref name="nasa.gov1"/> *MAWS 2<ref name="nasa.gov"/>
==Spacecraft for one== Historical spacecraft designed for single-person crews: *[[North American X-15]] (sub-orbital) *[[Vostok (spacecraft)]] *[[Mercury space capsule|Mercury capsule]] *[[Shenzhou 5]] (later designed to carry more people) *[[LK (spacecraft)]] *Copenhagen Suborbitals Tycho Brahe<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://newatlas.com/homebuilt-single-person-spacecraft-tested/18816/|title=Homebuilt $70,000 single-person spacecraft tested|website=newatlas.com|language=en|access-date=2018-02-05}}</ref>
In the early 2010s, a company in Denmark called [[Copenhagen Suborbitals]] built a design for a one-man spaceship for sub-orbital flight, powered by the HEAT 1-X rocket.<ref name="newatlas.com">{{cite web|url=https://newatlas.com/homebuilt-single-person-spacecraft-tested/18816/|title=Homebuilt $70,000 single-person spacecraft tested|website=newatlas.com}}</ref> The one-man spacecraft they called [[HEAT 1X Tycho Brahe|Tycho Brahe]] was not used in space or a manned sub-orbital flight.<ref name="newatlas.com" /> One in-atmosphere test flight of the prototype was conducted with a [[crash test dummy]].<ref>[http://news.softpedia.com/news/Danish-Manned-Spacecraft-Built-by-Volunteers-153441.shtml Danish Manned Spacecraft Built by Volunteers] Retrieved 25 August 2010</ref>
{| |[[File:Alan Shepard in capsule aboard Freedom 7 before launch.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Alan Shepard in the ''[[Mercury-Redstone 3|Freedom 7]]'' capsule before launch |alt=Shepard in his Mercury space suit and helmet, with tubes connected.]] |[[File:Mercury-cutaway.png|thumb|Cutaway diagram-art of the Mercury orbital spacecraft]] |[[File:X-15A2 NB-52B 3.jpg|thumb|right|X-15A2, with sealed ablative coating and [[Drop tank|external fuel tanks]] for a high-altitude rocket flight]] |}
==See also== *[[Space capsule]] *[[Space activity suit]] *[[Suitport]] *[[Mars suit]] *[[MOOSE]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[https://spaceflight.nasa.gov/gallery/images/vision/mars/html/jsc2004e19881.html Bottle-suit spacecraft and astronauts on EVA] * [http://cyberneticzoo.com/teleoperators/1954-bottle-suit-wernher-von-braun-walt-disney-american/ Von Braun Bottle] *[https://spaceflight.nasa.gov/gallery/images/vision/mars/html/jsc2004e19881.html Illustration includes some capsule spacecraft]
==Further reading == *[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20120013602.pdf Benefits of a Single-Person Spacecraft for Weightless Operations]

{{cleanup|date=October 2015|reason=Too simple, some parts are not written encyclopedically, focuses more on a semi-joking tone than an encyclopedic tone}} The '''tankero''' was originally a [[fiction]]al [[animal]] that was quite popular in [[Finland|Finnish]] media in the 1970s.
The word is said to have been coined when [[Prime Minister of Finland]] [[Ahti Karjalainen]] visited a [[Kenya]]n [[zoo]] in the 1970s. He is reported as having said ''"Kaikki eläimet ovat tankeroita"'' ([[Finnish language|Finnish]] for ''"All animals are ''tankeros''"''), after misunderstanding a sign that said ''"All animals are dangerous."''<ref>[http://www.yle.fi/elavaarkisto/artikkelit/ahti_karjalainen_avaa_etykin_ykkosvaiheen_35048.html#media=35050 Ahti Karjalainen avaa ETYKin ykkösvaiheen], [[YLE]] elävä arkisto. Accessed on 15 January 2013.</ref>
This was so popular that one Finnish magazine held a drawing competition of what the tankero would look like. The Finnish [[political cartoonist]] [[Kari Suomalainen]] drew a strip where [[Kalevi Sorsa]] meets Karjalainen and a strange-looking animal he is carrying on a leash. "Is that a tankero?" asks Sorsa, and the strange-looking animal replies "No, that's Ahti."
During the same period a certain number of jokes, based on English–Finnish language misunderstandings, were current: for example a person mistakenly greeting a [[Crimea]]n by calling him criminal. These jokes were labelled as "tankero jokes" and generally told with Ahti Karjalainen as the main character.
The original meaning fell into disuse after Karjalainen's death, and today it is a [[slang]] word for something that is awkward or not properly developed, especially poor knowledge of the [[pronunciation]] or [[grammar]] of a foreign language.
The most common use of the word ''tankero'' today is "tankero-englanti" or "tankero English", meaning poorly pronounced English. The term has very strong connotations of awkward-sounding pronunciation with a very strong Finnish accent. The actual grammar and vocabulary of "tankero English" may well be correct, though.
==See also== *[[Finglish]]
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Fictional animals]] [[Category:Finnish humour]]

page.title: The Quick and the Dead (1995 film)

revision.text:
{{Other uses|The Quick and the Dead (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox film | name = The Quick and the Dead | image = The-Quick-And-The-Dead-Poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Sam Raimi]] | producer = [[Joshua Donen]]
[[Patrick Markey]]
[[Allen Shapiro]] | writer = [[Simon Moore (writer)|Simon Moore]] | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Sharon Stone]] * [[Gene Hackman]] * [[Russell Crowe]] * [[Roberts Blossom]] * [[Kevin Conway (actor)|Kevin Conway]] * [[Lance Henriksen]] * [[Pat Hingle]] * [[Gary Sinise]] * [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] }} | music = [[Alan Silvestri]] | cinematography = [[Dante Spinotti]] | editing = [[Pietro Scalia]] | studio = {{Plainlist| * [[JSTV|Japan Satellite Broadcasting]] * IndieProd Company Productions }} | distributor = [[TriStar Pictures]] | released = {{film date|1995|2|10}} | runtime = 108 minutes{{cite web|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/quick-and-dead-1995|title=The Quick and the Dead|publisher=British Board of Film Classification|date=March 8, 1995|accessdate=July 5, 2017}} | country = United States{{cite web|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b7d41cf08|title=The Quick and the Dead|publisher=British Film Institute|accessdate=July 5, 2017}} | language = English | budget = $35 million{{cite book | author=[[John Kenneth Muir]] | title=The Unseen Force: The Films of Sam Raimi | year=2004 | publisher=Applause: Theatre & Cinema Books | location=New York City | pages=180–189 | isbn=1-55783-607-8}} | gross = $18.6 million (US){{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=quickandthedead.htm |title=The Quick and the Dead |work=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=2011-04-10}} }} '''''The Quick and the Dead''''' is a 1995 American [[western film]] directed by [[Sam Raimi]], and starring [[Sharon Stone]], [[Gene Hackman]], [[Russell Crowe]] and [[Leonardo DiCaprio]]. The screenplay was written by [[Simon Moore (writer)|Simon Moore]] but includes contributions from [[Joss Whedon]].{{cite web |url=http://spinoff.comicbookresources.com/2013/03/06/sam-raimi-explains-why-spider-man-4-didnt-happen/|title=Sam Raimi Explains Why Spider-Man 4 Didn’t Happen|publisher=Spinoff Online |accessdate=2014-08-21}} The story focuses on "The Lady" (Stone), a [[gunfighter]] who rides into the [[American frontier|frontier]] town of Redemption, controlled by John Herod (Hackman). The Lady joins a deadly dueling competition in an attempt to exact revenge for her father's death. Simon Moore's script was purchased by [[Sony Pictures Entertainment]] in May 1993, and actress Sharon Stone signed on as both star and co-producer. Development was [[wikt:Fast track|fast tracked]] after director Sam Raimi's hiring, and [[principal photography]] began in [[Old Tucson Studios]] in [[Arizona]] on November 21, 1993. The film was distributed by [[TriStar Pictures]] and was released in the US on February 10, 1995, to a dismal [[box office]] performance, receiving lukewarm reviews from critics. This was Russell Crowe's American film debut and was [[Woody Strode]]'s final performance (the film is dedicated to him), as well as the last theatrical release of [[Roberts Blossom]] who died in 2011. The phrase "[[The quick and the dead (idiom)|the quick and the dead]]" is from the [[Second Epistle to Timothy]] (2 Timothy 4:1) in various Bible versions, including the [[King James Bible]], describing the final judgment. The plot of this film bears no resemblance to that of the [[The Quick and the Dead (1987 film)|1987 film of the same name]], which was based on a western novel by [[Louis L'Amour]]. ==Plot== In 1881, a female gunslinger known only as The Lady arrives in the Old West town of Redemption, where she enters a [[bracket (tournament)|single elimination]] quick-draw contest held by Redemption's ruthless mayor and former outlaw, John Herod. She encounters the Blind Shoeshine Boy and a repulsive escaped convict named Scars, whose proposition she harshly rebuffs. At a sign-up meeting in the town saloon that night, the rules are explained: any contestant may challenge any other, no challenge can be refused, every contestant must fight once per day, and a fight continues until one contestant either yields or dies. While there she meets Cort, a former Herod henchman turned preacher whom Herod has captured and forced to enter the contest. The Lady saves Cort's life by shooting through the rope with which Herod's men try to hang him, then drunkenly spends the night with "The Kid", a brash young man who runs a gun store and hopes to impress Herod. Believing Herod to be his father, The Kid hopes to earn his respect by entering and winning the tournament. In the first round of duels, The Kid defeats a Swedish quick-draw champion while Herod kills a braggart named Ace Hanlon, who had taken credit for some of Herod's own accomplishments. The Lady defeats Dog Kelly, an enemy she had previously left shackled to a wagon. Since Cort has no money, Herod buys him a cheap, rusty gun and declares that he can only have one bullet at a time so that he cannot shoot his way out of town. Even though Cort has renounced violence, he draws on his exceptional skill as a gunfighter and wins his first-round duel. Before the second round begins, Herod meets with Clay Cantrell, a professional gunfighter hired by the townspeople to kill him. Before they duel, Herod changes the rules and proclaims that all contests are now to the death. After killing Cantrell, Herod angrily addresses the townspeople and informs them that he will continue to raise his taxes on them until they understand that he is in charge of everything. During a rainstorm that evening The Lady faces off with Eugene Dred after he rapes the saloon owner's young daughter. She shoots him in the genitals but spares his life and returns to the bar, but Dred ambushes her and she is ultimately forced to kill him. The next day, Cort is slated to fight Spotted Horse, a Native American who claims he "cannot be killed by a bullet". The Lady, still upset over killing Dred the night before, saddles up and rides out of town before Cort's fight. Cort narrowly beats Spotted Horse after having to beg for a second bullet. The Lady is found at a nearby cemetery by Doc Wallace, who tells her that he recognizes her and knows why she is there. During flashbacks, it is revealed that the Lady's real name is Ellen, and her father used to be the Marshal in Redemption until Herod invaded, killed all the deputies and had him strung up. Herod gave Ellen a pistol and three shots to try and break the rope her father was hanging from, but she accidentally killed him. Doc Wallace tells her that Herod's men dug up her father's body, burned it, and smashed his tombstone. He hands Ellen her father's old badge and begs her to come back and help rid the town of Herod, as she and Cort are now Redemption's only hope. Ellen rides back to town and directly challenges Herod but is sickened to hear that he has already accepted a fight against The Kid. Ellen and Cort are the only other fighters left and are ordered by Herod to face off, threatened with execution if neither of them draws on the other. The Kid turns down Herod's suggestion to withdraw from the contest; during their duel, Herod kills The Kid while suffering a wound to the neck. When Cort and Ellen face off, Cort begs her to kill him, then draws and fires on her. Doc Wallace declares Ellen dead; Cort angrily demands to fight Herod immediately, but settles for dawn of the next day. Ratsy, one of Herod's henchmen, beats Cort severely that night and breaks his right hand. The next morning, Herod angrily dismisses Ratsy from his service upon seeing Cort's injury, then kills him with a rifle as he tries to flee. He offers to fight Cort left-handed, but tells his henchmen to kill Cort if he wins. At the moment Herod draws, several buildings explode, including Herod's house and the clock tower. Ellen emerges from the smoke and flames, having faked her death with the help of Cort, Doc Wallace, and a bottle of red ink procured from the Blind Boy and having used The Kid's stash of dynamite. Cort kills Herod's men, and Ellen faces off against Herod, revealing her identity by throwing her father's badge at his feet. Herod wounds Ellen, but she shoots him through the chest and finishes him off with a bullet to the eye. Tossing the badge to Cort, she says, "The law's come back to town," then saddles up and rides away. ==Cast== [[Image:GeneHackmanJun08.jpg|thumb|175px|right|Gene Hackman portrayed John Herod, the film's main antagonist]] {{div col}} * [[Sharon Stone]] as Ellen ("The Lady") * [[Gene Hackman]] as John Herod * [[Russell Crowe]] as Cort * [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] as Fee "The Kid" Herod * [[Pat Hingle]] as Horace * [[Kevin Conway (actor)|Kevin Conway]] as Eugene Dred * [[Keith David]] as Sgt. Clay Cantrell * [[Lance Henriksen]] as Ace Hanlon * [[Mark Boone Junior]] as Scars * [[Tobin Bell]] as Dog Kelly * [[Raynor Scheine]] as Ratsy * [[Olivia Burnette]] as Katie * [[Roberts Blossom]] as Doc Wallace * [[Gary Sinise]] as The Marshal * [[Sven-Ole Thorsen]] as Swede Gutzon * [[Scott Spiegel]] as Gold Teeth Ma * [[Woody Strode]] as Charlie Moonlight * [[Bruce Campbell]] as Wedding Shemp {{div col end}} ==Production== ===Development=== Writer [[Simon Moore (writer)|Simon Moore]] finished his [[spec script]] for ''The Quick and the Dead'' in late 1992, writing it as a [[Homage (arts)|homage]] to the [[Spaghetti Western]]s of [[Sergio Leone]], particularly the ''[[Dollars Trilogy]]'' starring [[Clint Eastwood]]. The writer decided the lead character should be a female. "When you introduce women into that kind of world, something very interesting happens and you have an interesting dynamic straight away," Moore commented. The names of the lead villain ([[Herod the Great|Herod]]) and the town (Redemption) were intentional allusions to the Bible. Moore considered directing his own script as an [[independent film]] and shooting ''The Quick and the Dead'' on a $3–4 million budget in either Spain or Italy. [[Sony Pictures Entertainment]] purchased Moore's script in May 1993 and approached [[Sharon Stone]] to star in the lead role in July 1993.Muir, pp. 171-179 Because Stone also signed on as co-producer, she had approval over the choice of director. [[Sam Raimi]] was hired to direct because Stone was impressed with his work on ''[[Army of Darkness]]'' (1992). The actress told the producers that if Raimi did not direct the film, she would not star in it. Although she had mixed emotions on Raimi's previous work, she believed that the director still had yet to showcase his talents, feeling that ''The Quick and the Dead'' would be a perfect opportunity to "stretch the limits of his technical and creative ability."{{cite book | author = [[Bill Warren (film historian and critic)|Bill Warren]] | title = The Evil Dead Companion | month = | year = 2000 | publisher = [[Titan Books]] | location = London | chapter = Blood Still in the Veins | pages = 162–179 | ISBN = 0-312-27501-3}} Moore was also enthusiastic over Raimi's hiring, based on his previous work with the [[The Evil Dead (franchise)|''Evil Dead'' film series]]. When Sony began [[wikt:Fast track|fast tracking]] development ''The Quick and the Dead,'' the studio commissioned a series of rewrites from Moore. The writer was eventually dismissed and replaced with [[John Sayles]], who, according to Moore, took Sony's orders of "making more of an [[American Old West]] film." Moore was rehired with filming to begin in three weeks because Sayles' script was approaching a 2.5 hour runtime. When rewriting the [[shooting script]], Moore simply omitted Sayles' work without Sony noticing. A week before shooting, Sony considered the script good so that Moore described the rewrites "a completely fucking pointless exercise." ===Filming=== [[Russell Crowe]] originally auditioned for a different role in the film before Sharon Stone asked that the actor try for the lead male role. "When I saw ''[[Romper Stomper]]'' (1992), I thought Russell was not only charismatic, attractive and talented but also fearless," Stone reasoned. "And I find fearlessness very attractive. I was convinced I wouldn't scare him." Raimi found Crowe to be "bold and challenging. He reminds me of what we imagine the American cowboy to have been like."{{cite news | author = Jamie Diamond | title = Straight Out of Australia, to L.A. | work = [[The New York Times]] | date = 1995-03-26 }} On working with Raimi, Crowe later described the director as "sort of like the fourth [[The Three Stooges|Stooge]]." [[Image:Sam Raimi by David Shankbone.jpg|thumb|145px|left|Director Sam Raimi]] Sony Pictures was dubious over Stone's choice of Crowe because he was not a famous actor in the mid-1990s. To cast [[Gene Hackman]] in the role of Herod, [[TriStar Pictures]] changed the shooting location from [[Durango]], Mexico to [[Tucson, Arizona]].{{cite news | author = [[Army Archerd]] | url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117862241 | title = Douglas wows 'Greedy' cast, crew | date = 1993-08-16 | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | accessdate = 2009-03-07}} [[Sam Rockwell]] auditioned for The Kid, a role which ended up going to [[Leonardo DiCaprio]].{{cite news | author = Rebecca Murray; Fred Topel | url = http://movies.about.com/library/weekly/aaconfessionsintb.htm | title = Sam Rockwell Talks About ''Confessions of a Dangerous Mind'' | work = [[About.com]] | accessdate = 2009-03-07 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090227215636/http://movies.about.com/library/weekly/aaconfessionsintb.htm | archivedate = 2009-02-27 | df = }} Sony was also dubious over DiCaprio's casting. As a result, Stone decided to pay for the actor's salary herself. Filming was originally set to begin in October 1993, but was delayed because Crowe was busy on another film in Australia. [[Principal photography]] for ''The Quick and the Dead'' lasted from November 21, 1993 to February 27, 1994.{{cite news | author = Army Archerd | url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117862363 | title = Lemmon enjoying fruitful outings | date = 1993-10-13 | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | accessdate = 2009-03-07}}{{cite news | author = Army Archerd | url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117862435 | title = Friends stunned, saddened by Shore's death | date = 1994-02-25 | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | accessdate = 2009-03-07}} Locations included [[Old Tucson Studios]] in Arizona and Mescal, 40 miles southeast of Tucson. Production was briefly halted at times over weather problems. [[Thell Reed (Shooter)|Thell Reed]], who was hired as the gun coach and [[weapons master]], worked with the cast through over three months of training. To age Cort's [[Colt 1851 Navy Revolver]] and the other guns used, Reed experimented with simple measures. "I took them out by my swimming pool and dipped them in chlorine water to let them rust," he explained. "They looked rusty and old, but were brand new guns." Such detail, including the [[nickel]] plating and ivory handles on Ellen's [[Colt Single Action Army|Colt Peacemakers]], was accurate to the time period.Muir, pp.190-197 The town of Redemption was designed by [[Patrizia von Brandenstein]], known for her work on ''[[Amadeus (film)|Amadeus]]'' (1984) and ''[[The Untouchables (film)|The Untouchables]]'' (1987). Raimi's first choice as the [[visual effects supervisor]] was William Mesa, his collaborator on ''[[Darkman]]'' (1991) and ''[[Army of Darkness]]'' (1993). Instead, Sony chose [[Framestore|The Computer Film Company]] to create the VFX sequences. [[Pick-up (filmmaking)|Pick-up]] scenes took place through November - December 1994. This included an extended duel between Sharon Stone and Gene Hackman.{{cite news | author = Army Archerd | url = http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117862606 | title = H'w'd pumped for sequel to 'Gump' | date = 1994-12-20 | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | accessdate = 2009-03-07}} Stone had a love scene removed from the final cut of ''The Quick and the Dead'' before the film's release in the United States.{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Ck9WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vOsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6765,2873726&dq=quick-and-the-dead+stone&hl=en |title=Winnie Mandela Caught in New Flap|publisher=Eugene Register-Guard|accessdate=2011-02-19|date= 1995-02-12 }} The actress/co-producer thought the scene did not fit in with the picture's established reality. It was restored for the home cinema releases of the film. ===Soundtrack=== The original motion picture soundtrack for ''The Quick and the Dead'', was released by the [[Varèse Sarabande]] music label on February 14, 1995.{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0000014WE |title=The Quick and the Dead Soundtrack |publisher=Amazon.com |accessdate=2011-04-10}} The score for the film was composed and conducted by [[Alan Silvestri]] and mixed by [[Dennis S. Sands|Dennis Sands]]. Kenneth Karman and Thomas Drescher edited the film's music.{{cite web|url=https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/1800342120/cast |title=The Quick and the Dead (1995) |accessdate=2011-04-10 |publisher=Yahoo! Movies}} {{Infobox album | name = The Quick and the Dead: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack | type = [[Film score]] | artist = [[Alan Silvestri]] | cover = TQATDSoundtrack.jpg | alt = | released = February 14, 1995 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = 31:01 | label = Varèse Sarabande | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} {{Track listing | collapsed = no | headline = ''The Quick and the Dead: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack'' | total_length = 31:01 | title1 = Redemption | length1 = 3:25 | title2 = Gunfight Montage | length2 = 1:41 | title3 = Couldn't Tell Us Apart | length3 = 1:17 | title4 = John Herod | length4 = 1:21 | title5 = Ellen's First Round | length5 = 1:10 | title6 = Lady's the Winner | length6 = 0:47 | title7 = Dinner Tonight | length7 = 2:11 | title8 = Cort's Story | length8 = 1:02 | title9 = Ellen vs. Dred | length9 = 1:10 | title10 = Kid vs. Herod | length10 = 4:17 | title11 = I Don't Wanna Die | length11 = 2:00 | title12 = The Big Day | length12 = 2:27 | title13 = Ellen Returns | length13 = 3:54 | title14 = The Law's Come Back to Town | length14 = 0:49 | title15 = The Quick and the Dead (End Credits) | length15 = 3:30 }} ==Release== ===Box office=== ''The Quick and the Dead'' was released in the U.S. on February 10, 1995 in 2,158 theaters, earning $6,515,861 in its opening weekend. The film eventually grossed $18,636,537 in at the US box office and was declared to be a [[box office bomb]]. Writer Simon Moore noted that the film performed modestly in Europe. ''The Quick and the Dead''' faced competition at the box office from ''[[Billy Madison]]'', ''[[The Brady Bunch Movie]]'', ''[[Just Cause (film)|Just Cause]]'' and ''[[Heavyweights]]''.{{cite web | url = http://www.the-numbers.com/charts/weekly/1995/19950217.php | title = The Top Movies, Weekend of February 17, 1995 | work = The Numbers | accessdate = 2009-03-10}} Director Sam Raimi later blamed himself and his visual style for the film's failure. "I was very confused after I made that movie. For a number of years I thought, I'm like a dinosaur. I couldn't change with the material." [[TriStar Pictures]] also showed ''The Quick and the Dead'' as an "out-of-competition" film at the May [[1995 Cannes Film Festival]].{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/3381/year/1995.html |title=Festival de Cannes: The Quick and the Dead |accessdate=2009-09-08|work=festival-cannes.com}} Additionally, Stone was nominated for the [[Saturn Award for Best Actress]], but lost to [[Angela Bassett]] in ''[[Strange Days (film)|Strange Days]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.saturnawards.org/past.html |title=Past Saturn Awards |work=Academy of Science Fiction, Fantasy & Horror Films |accessdate=2009-03-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080207072429/http://www.saturnawards.org/past.html |archivedate=2008-02-07 |df= }} A [[novelization]] written by [[Jack Curtis (writer)|Jack Curtis]] was published by [[HarperCollins]] in September 1995.{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.com/dp/0006496512 | title = The Quick and the Dead (Paperback) | work = [[Amazon.com]] | accessdate = 2009-03-09}} The [[DVD region code|Region 1 DVD]] release came in September 1998.{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.com/dp/0767817710/ | title = The Quick and the Dead (1995) | work = [[Amazon.com]] | accessdate = 2009-03-09}} ===Critical reception=== ''The Quick and the Dead'' received mixed reviews from film critics. Based on 41 reviews, [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the film a score of 56%, with an average rating of 5.9/10.{{cite web | title=The Quick and the Dead (1995) | url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1059629-quick_and_the_dead/ | work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | accessdate=2009-03-11}} [[Metacritic]] calculated an average score of 49/100, based on 21 reviews.{{cite web | title=The Quick and the Dead (1995): Reviews | url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/quickandthedead | work=[[Metacritic]] | accessdate=2009-03-11}} [[Janet Maslin]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' praised Stone's performance and Raimi's directing. "Stone's presence nicely underscores the genre-bending tactics of Raimi, the [[cult film]]maker now doing his best to reinvent the [[B movie]] in a spirit of self-referential glee."{{cite news | author=[[Janet Maslin]] | title=The Quick and the Dead | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=1995-02-10}} [[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' criticized the film for being overtly [[cliché]], but praised Raimi's direction and [[Dante Spinotti]]'s [[cinematographer|cinematography]].{{cite news | author = [[Roger Ebert]] | url = http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19950210/REVIEWS/502100302/1023 | title = The Quick and the Dead | work = [[Chicago Sun-Times]] | date = 1995-02-10 | accessdate = 2009-03-11}} Critic and Raimi biographer [[Bill Warren (film historian and critic)|Bill Warren]] wrote that the film "is a very conscious (though not self-conscious) attempt to recreate some of the themes, style and appeal of [[Sergio Leone]]'s majestically operatic [[Spaghetti Western]]s of the 1960s, especially the [[Man with No Name]] trilogy that starred [[Clint Eastwood]]. It's brisker, more romantic and somehow more American than Leone's movies." {| class="toccolours" style="float: left; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; background:#FFFFE0; color:black; width:30em; max-width: 40%;" cellspacing="5" | style="text-align: left;" |"The cinematographer, Dante Spinotti (''[[The Last of the Mohicans (1992 film)|The Last of the Mohicans]]'') makes the material look terrific. The lowering skies around the isolated town make it look ripe for vengeance of biblical proportions, and there are quiet satirical touches, as when a man stands in a saloon door and his shadow seems about 6 miles long." |- | style="text-align: left;" |—Roger Ebert, writing in the ''Chicago Sun-Times'' |} [[Jonathan Rosenbaum]] of the ''[[Chicago Reader]]'' observed that "Raimi tries to do a Sergio Leone, and though ''The Quick and the Dead'' is highly enjoyable in spots, it doesn't come across as very convincing, perhaps because nothing can turn Sharon Stone into [[Charles Bronson]]."{{cite news | author=[[Jonathan Rosenbaum]] | title=The Quick and the Dead | url=http://onfilm.chicagoreader.com/movies/capsules/12414_QUICK_AND_THE_DEAD | work=[[Chicago Reader]] | accessdate=2009-03-11}} [[Peter Travers]] of [[Rolling Stone]] felt that "''The Quick and the Dead'' plays like a crazed compilation of highlights from famous westerns. Raimi finds the right look but misses the heartbeat. You leave the film dazed instead of dazzled, as if an expert marksman had drawn his gun only to shoot himself in the foot."{{cite news | author=[[Peter Travers]] | title=The Quick and the Dead | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/the-quick-and-the-dead-19950101 | work=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=1995-03-09 | accessdate=2011-03-10}} {{-}} ==See also== {{Portal|Film}} * [[1995 in film]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote|The Quick and the Dead}} * {{official website|http://www.sonypictures.com/movies/thequickandthedead/}} * {{IMDb title|id=0114214|title=The Quick and the Dead}} * {{Amg movie|132303|The Quick and the Dead}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|id=1059629-quick_and_the_dead|title=The Quick and the Dead}} * {{mojo title|id=quickandthedead|title=The Quick and the Dead}} {{Sam Raimi}} {{good article}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Quick and the Dead, The (1995 film)}} [[Category:1995 films]] [[Category:1990s adventure films]] [[Category:1990s drama films]] [[Category:1990s Western (genre) films]] [[Category:American adventure drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American Western (genre) films]] [[Category:Films scored by Alan Silvestri]] [[Category:Films about death]] [[Category:Films about revenge]] [[Category:Films directed by Sam Raimi]] [[Category:Films set in 1881]] [[Category:Films shot in Arizona]] [[Category:Girls with guns films]] [[Category:TriStar Pictures films]]

revision.text:
{{other uses|Third eye (disambiguation)}} [[File:Shiva Musée Guimet 22971.jpg|thumb|A Cambodian [[Shiva]] head showing a third eye.]] The '''third eye''' (also called the '''mind's eye''', or '''inner eye''') is a mystical and [[esoteric]] concept of a speculative invisible eye which provides perception beyond ordinary sight.<ref name=MMM>{{cite book|title=Man, Myth and Magic – Volume 19|year=1994|publisher=Marshall Cavendish|location=New York, NY|isbn=0839360355|page=2606|editor=Richard Cavendish}}</ref>
==Religious overview== In certain dharmic spiritual traditions the third eye refers to the [[ajna]] (or brow) [[chakra]].<ref name=Saraswati>{{cite book|last=Saraswati|first=Swami Satyananda Saraswati|title=Kundalini iuuuggTantra|year=2001|publisher=Yoga I Publications Trust|location=Bihar, India|isbn=978-8185787152}}</ref> The third eye refers to the gate that leads to inner realms and spaces of [[higher consciousness]]. In [[New Age]] spirituality, the third eye often [[symbol]]izes a state of [[enlightenment (spiritual)|enlightenment]] or the evocation of [[mental image]]s having deeply personal [[spirituality|spiritual]] or [[psychological]] significance. The third eye is often associated with [[vision (religion)|religious visions]], [[clairvoyance]], the ability to observe [[chakra]]s and [[aura (paranormal)|auras]],<ref name="Leadbeater, C.W. Page 79">Leadbeater, C.W. ''The Chakras'' Wheaton, Illinois, USA:1927 Theosophical Publishing House Page 79.</ref> [[precognition]], and [[out-of-body experience]]s. People who are claimed to have the capacity to utilize their third eyes are sometimes known as ''seers''. In [[Hinduism]], the third eye is said to be located around the middle of the forehead, slightly above the junction of the eyebrows.
In [[Taoism]] and many traditional Chinese religious sects such as Chan (called [[Zen]] in Japanese), "third eye training" involves focusing attention on the point between the eyebrows with the eyes closed, and while the body is in various [[qigong]] postures. The goal of this training is to allow students to tune into the correct "vibration" of the universe and gain a solid foundation on which to reach more advanced meditation levels. Taoism teaches that the third eye, also called the [[mind's eye]], is situated between the two physical eyes, and expands up to the middle of the forehead when opened. Taoism claims that the third eye is one of the main energy centers of the body located at the sixth [[Chakra]], forming a part of the main meridian, the line separating left and right hemispheres of the body.<ref>The doctrine of the elixir by R.B. Jefferson Coombe Springs Press 1982 chapter 4. The Archaic Anatomy of Individual Organs.</ref> In Taoist alchemical traditions, the third eye is the frontal part of the "Upper Dan Tien" (upper cinnabar field) and is given the evocative name "muddy pellet".
According to the Christian teaching of Father [[Richard Rohr]], the concept of the third eye is a metaphor for non-dualistic thinking; the way the mystics see. In Rohr's concept, mystics employ the first eye (sensory input such as sight) and the second eye (the eye of reason, meditation, and reflection), "but they know not to confuse knowledge with depth, or mere correct information with the transformation of consciousness itself. The mystical gaze builds upon the first two eyes—and yet goes further." Rohr refers to this level of awareness as "having the mind of Christ".<ref>Rohr, Richard "The Naked Now: Learning to See as the Mystics See", The Crossroad Publishing Company, 2009, {{ISBN|0-8245-2543-4}}, {{ISBN|978-0-8245-2543-9}}.</ref>
Adherents of [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|theosophist]] [[H.P. Blavatsky]]<ref>H.P. Blavatsky, ''[http://www.theosociety.org/pasadena/sd/sd-hp.htm The Secret Doctrine]'', Vol. 2, 1888, {{ISBN|1-55700-124-3}}, pp. 289-306.</ref> have suggested that the third eye is in fact the partially dormant [[pineal gland]], which resides between the two hemispheres of the brain. [[Reptile]]s and [[amphibian]]s sense light via a third [[parietal eye]]—a structure associated with the pineal gland—which serves to regulate their [[circadian rhythm]]s, and for navigation, as it can sense the polarization of light. [[C.W. Leadbeater]] claimed that by extending an "etheric tube" from the third eye, it is possible to develop microscopic and telescopic vision.<ref name="Leadbeater, C.W. Page 79"/> It has been asserted by Stephen Phillips that the third eye's microscopic vision is capable of observing objects as small as [[quark]]s.<ref>Phillips, Stephen ''Extrasensory Perception of Quarks'' Wheaton, Illinois, USA 1980 Theosophical Publishing House {{ISBN|978-0-8356-0227-3}}.</ref> According to this belief, humans had in far ancient times an actual third eye in the back of the head with a physical and spiritual function. Over time, as humans evolved, this eye atrophied and sunk into what today is known as the pineal gland.<ref name="Helena Petrovna Blavatsky 1993">Helena Petrovna Blavatsky, ''The Secret Doctrine'' vol. II, (Wheaton, IL: Theosophical Publishing House, 1993), 295.</ref> Dr. [[Rick Strassman]] has hypothesized that the pineal gland, which maintains light sensitivity, is responsible for the production and release of [[Dimethyltryptamine|DMT]] (dimethyltryptamine), an [[entheogen]] which he believes possibly could be excreted in large quantities at the moments of birth and death.<ref name="strassman">{{cite book |title=DMT: The Spirit Molecule. A Doctor's Revolutionary Research into the Biology of Near-Death and Mystical Experiences |last=Strassman |first=Rick J. |authorlink=Rick Strassman |year=2001 |publisher=Park Street |location=Rochester, Vt |isbn=978-0-89281-927-0}} ({{cite web | url=http://rickstrassman.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=61&Itemid=60 | title=Chapter summaries | accessdate=27 February 2012}})</ref>
== Philosophy == The use of the phrase ''mind's eye'' does not imply that there is a single or unitary place in the mind or brain where visual consciousness occurs. Philosophers such as [[Daniel Dennett]] have critiqued this view.<ref>''Consciousness Explained'', Daniel C. Dennett, Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1991. {{ISBN|0-316-18065-3}}.</ref> However, others, such as [[Johnjoe McFadden]] of the [[University of Surrey]] in the [[United Kingdom]] and the New Zealand-based neurobiologist [[Susan Pockett]], propose that the brain's [[electromagnetic field]] is consciousness itself, thus causing the perception of a unitary location.<ref>[http://unisci.com/stories/20022/0516026.htm Our Conscious Mind Could Be An Electromagnetic Field], UniSci.</ref><ref>[http://www.surrey.ac.uk/qe/pdfs/cemi_theory_paper.pdf Synchronous Firing and Its Influence on the Brain's Electromagnetic Field: Evidence for an Electromagnetic Field Theory of Consciousness], J. McFadden, ''Journal of Consciousness Studies'' '''9''' (2002), part 4, pp. 23–50.</ref>
==See also== {{Wikiquote}} {{commons category|Ajna chakra (third eye)}} *[[Eye of Providence]] *[[Consciousness]] *[[Ajna|Ajna chakra]] *[[Parietal eye]] *[[Pineal gland]] *[[Erlang Shen]]

==References== * Hale, Teresa (1999). ''The Book of Chakra Healing''. New York: Sterling Publishing Company. {{ISBN|0-8069-2097-1}}. * Radha, Siviananda (2004). ''Kundalini Yoga for the West''. New York: Shambhala. {{ISBN|1-932018-04-2}}. * Sagan, Samuel, M.D. (2007). ''Awakening the Third Eye'' (3rd ed). Roseville, N.S.W., Australia: Clairvision. {{ISBN|0-9586700-5-6}}. * Sharp, Dr. Michael (2005). ''Dossier of the Ascension: A Practical Guide to Chakra Activation and Kundalini Awakening''. St. Albert, Alberta: Avatar Publications. {{ISBN|0-9735379-3-0}}.

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Tom Adamson | image = | fullname = Thomas Kay Adamson<ref name="Joyce" /> | birth_date =12 February 1901 | birth_place = [[Mossend]], Scotland | death_date = | position = [[Left back]] |youthyears1 = |youthclubs1 = [[Blantyre Celtic F.C.|Blantyre Celtic]] |youthyears2 = |youthclubs2 = [[Bellshill Athletic F.C.|Bellshill Athletic]] | years1 = 1921–1928 | clubs1=[[Bury F.C.|Bury]] | caps1=271 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 1929–1934 | clubs2=[[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] | caps2=141 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 1934 | clubs3=[[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] | caps3=0 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = | clubs4= | caps4= | goals4 = |manageryears1 = 1935 |managerclubs1 = [[Ards F.C.|Ards]] }}
'''Thomas Kay Adamson''' was a Scottish professional [[association football|football]] [[left back]] and [[Manager (association football)|manager]], best remembered for his time in the [[Football League]] with [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] and [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]].<ref name="Timeless">{{Cite book |title=Timeless Bees: Brentford F.C. Who's Who 1920–2006 |last=Haynes |first=Graham |last2=Coumbe |first2=Frank |publisher=Yore Publications |year=2006 |isbn=978-0955294914 |location=Harefield |page=8}}</ref> He later had a short tenure as manager of [[Irish Football League|Irish League]] side [[Ards F.C.|Ards]].<ref name="Timeless" />
== Playing career ==
=== Early years === A [[left back]], Adamson began his career at [[Football in Scotland|Scottish]] junior clubs [[Blantyre Celtic F.C.|Blantyre Celtic]] and [[Bellshill Athletic F.C.|Bellshill Athletic]].<ref name="Timeless" />
=== Bury === Adamson moved to [[Football in England|England]] to join [[Football League Division Two|Division Two]] side [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] in 1921.<ref name="Timeless" /> Over the course of seven years at [[Gigg Lane]], Adamson made 271 appearances and helped the Shakers to promotion back to [[Football League Division One|Division One]] in the [[1923–24 Football League|1923–24]] season.<ref name="Timeless" />
=== Brentford === Adamson dropped down to the [[Division Three South]] to sign for [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] prior to the beginning of the [[1929–30 Brentford F.C. season|1929–30]] season.<ref name="Timeless" /> He immediately broke into the team and made 36 appearances during his debut season,<ref name="White2">{{Cite book|title=100 Years Of Brentford|publisher=Brentford FC|year=1989|isbn=0951526200|editor-last=White|editor-first=Eric|pages=370–372}}</ref> a campaign memorable for the Bees record-breaking 21 home wins.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/club/history/|title=Brentford FC History|last=History|website=www.brentfordfc.co.uk|access-date=19 December 2016}}</ref> Adamson was a mainstay of the side for the following two seasons and made 28 appearances to help the Bees into Division Two for the first time in the club's history in the [[1932–33 Brentford F.C. season|1932–33]] season, winning the Division Three South title.<ref name="White2" /> Age caught up to Adamson and he made just eight appearances during the [[1933–34 Brentford F.C. season|1933–34]] season and departed [[Griffin Park]] at the end of the campaign.<ref name="Timeless" /><ref name="White2" /> Adamson made 153 appearances in four years with the Bees.<ref name="Timeless" />
=== Stockport County === Adamson returned to the [[Manchester]] area to sign for [[Division Three North]] side [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] in 1934.<ref name="Timeless" /> He failed to make an appearance for the club and ended his career having failed to score in over 400 professional matches.<ref name="Joyce">{{Cite book|title=Football League Players' Records 1888 to 1939|last=Joyce|first=Michael|publisher=Tony Brown|year=2012|isbn=190589161X|location=Nottingham|page=5|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref>
== Managerial career == Adamson had a short spell as [[Manager (association football)|manager]] of [[Irish Football League|Irish League]] side [[Ards F.C.|Ards]] in 1935.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.online.no/~smogols/ifcp/clubs/ards/managersards.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151031125920/http://home.online.no/~smogols/ifcp/clubs/ards/managersards.htm|archivedate=31 October 2015|title=Irish Football Club Project – Ards Football Club – Managers|work=online.no|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> Former Brentford full back partner [[Alexander Stevenson (footballer)|Alexander Stevenson]] was one of his signings.<ref name="Timeless" />
== Personal life == While growing up, Adamson went to school with future [[Scotland national football team|Scottish internationals]] [[Hughie Gallacher]] and [[Alex James (footballer)|Alex James]].<ref name="Timeless" />
== Honours == '''[[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]]''' * [[Football League Third Division South]]: [[1932–33 Brentford F.C. season|1932–33]]<ref name="White2" />
== Career statistics == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! rowspan="2" |Club ! rowspan="2" |Season ! colspan="3" |League ! colspan="2" |FA Cup ! colspan="2" |Total |- !Division !Apps !Goals !Apps !Goals !Apps !Goals |- | rowspan="5" |[[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] |[[1929–30 Brentford F.C. season|1929–30]]<ref name="White2" /> | rowspan="4" |[[Football League Third Division South|Third Division South]] |35 |0 |1 |0 |36 |0 |- |[[1930–31 Brentford F.C. season|1930–31]]<ref name="White2" /> |36 |0 |5 |0 |41 |0 |- |[[1931–32 Brentford F.C. season|1931–32]]<ref name="White2" /> |35 |0 |5 |0 |40 |0 |- |[[1932–33 Brentford F.C. season|1932–33]]<ref name="White2" /> |27 |0 |1 |0 |28 |0 |- |[[1933–34 Brentford F.C. season|1933–34]]<ref name="White2" /> |[[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] |8 |0 |0 |0 |8 |0 |- ! colspan="3" |Career total !141 !0 !12 !0 !153 !0 |}

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} An '''V0-morph''' is an [[organism]] that changes in shape during growth such that its surface area is proportional to its volume to the power 0, so its surface area is constant.
The reason why the concept is important in the context of the [[Dynamic Energy Budget]] theory is that food (substrate) uptake is proportional to surface area, and maintenance to volume. The surface area that is of importance is that part that is involved in substrate uptake.
[[Biofilm]]s on a flat solid substrate are examples of V0-morphs; they grow in thickness, but not in surface area that is involved in nutrient exchange. Other examples are [[dinophyta]] and [[diatom]]s that have a cell wall that does not change during the cell cycle. During cell-growth, when the amounts of protein and carbohydrates increase, the vacuole shrinks. The outer membrane that is involved in nutrient uptake remains constant. At cell division, the daughter cells rapidly take up water, complete a new cell wall and the cycle repeats.
[[Eubacteria|Rod]]s (bacteria that have the shape of a rod and grow in length, but not in diameter) are a '''static mixture''' between a V0- and a [[V1-morph]], where the caps act as V0-morphs and the cylinder between the caps as V1-morph.The mixture is called static because the weight coefficients of the contributions of the V0- and V1-morph terms in the [[shape correction function]] are constant during growth.
[[Crust (geology)|Crust]]s, such as [[lichen]]s that grow on a solid substrate, are a '''dynamic mixture''' between a V0- and a V1-morph, where the inner part acts as V0-morph, and the outer annulus as V1-morph.The mixture is called dynamic because the weight coefficients of the contributions of the V0- and V1-morph terms in the [[shape correction function]] change during growth.The [[Dynamic Energy Budget]] theory explains why the diameter of crusts grow linearly in time at constant substrate availability.
==References== {{reflist}}
==See also== * [[Dynamic energy budget]] * [[isomorph]] * [[V1-morph]] * [[shape correction function]]
